items.title: An integrative approach to the study of drift-diffusion dynamics in working memory
items.author: Junlian Luo, David Pascucci
items.content: <article>In this issue of Neuron, Gu et al. demonstrate how two canonical working memory biases emerge and interact, integrating behavior, neuroimaging, and recurrent neural network modeling. The findings provide convergent evidence that drift and diffusion dynamics underlie the gradual shaping of memory states over time.</article>

items.title: Taking the exit ramp—How the brain determines when to leave
items.author: Adithya E. Rajagopalan, Christine M. Constantinople
items.content: <article>In this issue of Neuron, leveraging naturalistic behavior, multi-regional electrophysiology, and computational approaches, Bukwich et al. show that ramping activity in frontal cortices reflects mechanistic processes that underlie normative models of foraging decisions about when to leave resource patches.</article>

items.title: A “backseat driver” calls out directions in the mouse visual thalamus
items.author: Kierra C. Mason, Martha E. Bickford
items.content: <article>Across mammals, the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus (dLGN) is innervated by the superior colliculus (SC). In this issue of Neuron, Fei et al. employ a colorful approach to probe this pathway and find that within the dLGN retinal and SC, inputs collaborate to code the direction of visual movement.</article>

items.title: Friendship fights cancer
items.author: Antonio V. Aubry, Scott J. Russo
items.content: <article>In this issue of Neuron, Wen et al. reveal that social interaction activates an ACC→BLA circuit in female breast cancer model mice, reducing anxiety, norepinephrine, and tumor growth. Circuit manipulations shift immunity toward cytotoxic T cells, uncovering a brain-immune pathway translating companionship into antitumor effects.</article>

items.title: Identification of the peptide Vulnusin, a wound signal that mediates mechanical-injury-induced nociception in Drosophila
items.author: Yanmeng Guo, Tun Li, Sami T. Tuomivaara, Chin Fen Teo, Shengjie Feng, Robert J. Chalkley, Ruijun Zhu, Tong Cheng, Kathy H. Li, Wei Chen, Avi Simon, Peng Jin, Susan Younger, Adeline J.H. Yong, Kai Li, Kexin Li, Alma L. Burlingame, Lily Yeh Jan, Yuh Nung Jan
items.content: <article>Guo et al. identify the peptide Vulnusin as an acute wound signal that activates C4da nociceptors through the PPK1/PPK26 ion channel in Drosophila larvae. Vulnusin localizes in the extracellular space apical to the epidermis when uninjured but reaches the C4da nociceptor upon damage to trigger the nociceptive rolling behavior.</article>

items.title: Neuromorphic is dead. Long live neuromorphic.
items.author: Giacomo Indiveri
items.content: <article>In this NeuroView, Giacomo Indiveri discusses the origins and evolution of neuromorphic engineering, reflects on recent shifts toward digital and AI-centric approaches, and advocates for a revival of the field’s original principles, emphasizing analog, brain-inspired systems and the importance of fundamental neuroscience for future progress.</article>
